Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Analysis on Sympletic, Complex Manifolds, General Relativity, and Graphs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1308244, Principal Investigator: Shing-Tung Yau

There are several directions that we shall carry out in this proposal. 1. Symplectic geometry and periods of algebraic manifolds: We shall study extensively the new cohomological invariants for symplectic geometry introduced by Tseng and myself, which may be considered as generalization of Bott-Chern cohomology. We shall also study the mirror counterpart of this cohomology and interpret the role of the supersymmetric equations in II A and II B theories in this new cohomology. Many examples will be calculated to support our theory. For deeper understanding of the theory of mirror symmetry, we shall also calculate periods of algebraic manifolds which are not toric. Power method of D-modules will be used. 2. Gromov-Witten invariants and Calabi-Yau manifolds with elliptic vibrations: We shall extend my previous work with Yamaguchi to study the ring of higher loop amplitude in string theory. We shall give more refined structure to this ring and try to construct analogous properties of it that are close to classical automorphic form theory. We also like to understand in a deeper manner the singular structure of the degeneration of elliptic fiber structure of Calabi-Yau manifolds. They have interesting physical meaning. 3. SYZ construction of mirror manifolds: We like to study the affine structure that appears in this construction. Interesting equations will be solved. 4. Construction of balanced metric through understanding of twistor construction: Nonkahler geometry is playing an increasingly important role in string theory. We shall explore such balanced metrics. 5. Quasilocal mass in general relativity: Mu-Tao Wang, Po-Ning Chen, and I will continue to study the important quasilocal mass that Wang and I introduced. We hope to seek the important property of this mass and hopefully use it to study dynamics of Einstein equation. 6. Invariants of graph theory: We are developing intrinsic cohomology theory to directed graphs. We believe that we can construct rich invariant based on our construction.

Overall, we are applying geometric methods to solve important questions in new fronts of geometry that are closely related to physics, such as string theory and general relativity. The works on graph theory pioneer a new direction to understand complex networks which have fundamental importance in computer science and other areas of mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Manifolds are fundamental objects of study in mathematics. These could be more general than Cartesian spaces, for instance they can have nonzero (positive or negative) curvature, or a variety of metrics with different properties with which one could define the notion of distance on them. After Einstein's theory of General Relativity (GR), which predicted that the presence of matter in the space-time continuum affects its geometry, the study of manifolds and their connections to relativistic mechanics became a major field of mathematics.

On a manifold with complex structure, a Kähler-Einstein metric is the one which satisfies the property of being both Kähler and Einstein simultaneously. Roughly speaking, being an Einstein metric on a Riemannian (or pseudo-Riemannian) differentiable manifold is equivalent to saying the metric is obtained as the solution to Einstein's vacuum field equations, that is the Einstein's field equations when the stress-energy tensor is set equal to zero (i.e. no matter in space). Being Kähler, on the other hand, is equivalent to saying that locally around any point on the manifold one can define the metric with respect to the (2-fold) tensor product of first order derivatives of holomorphic coordinate functions defined on a neighborhood of such point. The proof of existence of a a Kähler-Einstein metric on complex manifolds is of major importance both in differential geometry and GR. The PI, in collaboration with Damin Wu, proved that manifolds with strongly negative holomorphic sectional curvature admit a Kähler-Einstein metrics. This is an important outcome from many points of view, and answered a conjecture of the PI (published in Inventiones, 2016). For instance it provides one with a better understanding of the geometry of black holes. The PI also used algebraic methods to answer major questions in complex analytic geometry. Many major examples of Kähler manifolds often come from algebraic geometry. The PI and Wu used algebraic methods to prove statements about Kähler-Einstein metrics on non-compact complex analytic spaces. In fact, they were able to make a bridge between singularity theory and complex analytic geometry and gave a classification of non-compact analytic spaces which cannot have Kähler-Einstein metric on them. This solved an open problem in the field.

Besides the geometric approach, the PI has made direct progress in the physics of GR itself; in special relativity, the rest mass of a particle is defined to be the minimum value of energy seen among all observers, however the concept of resting mass in GR is more involved. This motivated the PI, Po-Ning Chen, and Mu-Tao Wang to come up with such definition as the minimum value of energy among observers for a space of constant negative curvature, called Anti-de Sitter space. The Anti-de Sitter space has the property that in the absence of matter or energy its curvature is negative, a phenomenon corresponding to a negative cosmological constant.

One other outcome of the PI's work has been the study of superconformal field theories (SCFT) in string theory over 4-dimensional manifolds. A conformal quantum field theory is invariant under conformal transformations of the underlying space of that theory, that is, the transformations applied to the base space (here the 4-dimensional manifolds) which locally preserve the angles. These local transformations can mathematically be realized as the action of symmetry groups on the underlying space, and in the case of SCFT, they are realized as supersymmetric groups. The SCFTs are important since they provide many interesting insights about the mathematics of 4-dimensional manifolds, for instance Seiberg-Witten theory or the theory of instanton counting on them. The major outcome of the PI's collaboration with Dan Xie in this direction has been the classification of SCFTs with respect to classification of hypersurface singularities in ambient 3-complex dimensional spaces. Moreover, and besides the classification problem mentioned above, the PI and Xie studied the correspondence between 4D SCFT and 2D chiral algebras. It is a known fact that 4-dimensional SCFTs induce algebraic structures, called chiral algebras, which could have 2D conformal models. This means roughly that the observables of the 4D SCFT can be identified with observables of 2D conformal field theories, and the major work of the PI and Xie in this direction has been showing that; how the information of a 2D chiral algebra can be used to recover a 4D Argyres-Douglas SCFT theory on a 4-dimensional manifold. Finally, the other research direction taken by the PI and Gabor Lippner, Yang Lin, and Mark Kempton has been the study of the relationship between graphs and discrete differential geometry, where they came up with a few conjectures on the existence of graphs embeddable into orientable surfaces.
